awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project - Building on A Foundation of Stone: The Future Growth of Wiley College's Division of Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Wiley College seeks to establish strategies to strengthen and enhance STEM teaching, learning, and research and to improve students' access to and retention in STEM programs. Eighty-five percent of the students at Wiley College are African-American, with a growing number of Hispanic students. Most of the students are first-generation college students and/or are from low socio-economic backgrounds. The project seeks to implement interventions and strategies to increase the academic preparation of the students seeking graduate degrees in a STEM field that can serve as models for other institutions with open admission policies.

The following activities are proposed: a six week long pre-college Mathematics camp and new minors in Computer Sciences and Physics to strengthen students' quantitative skills; an interdisciplinary STEM journal club and an undergraduate research program to prepare students for graduate studies; and professional development for faculty and support staff.  Wiley College seeks to share and disseminate evidence-based best practices and findings on retention, academic engagement, and enhancement of STEM undergraduate majors, particularly at conferences for open door admission institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to identify and recruit talented under-represented minority youth and engage them in a pre-college STEM enrichment program and to involve college-level STEM majors in hands-on faculty mentored research.   

  

STEMulate Summer Science and Math Camp  

Wiley College has run a summer pre-college science and math camp for the years 2015-2019. Though we were unable to maintain STEMulate in 2020 and 2021 due to COVID restrictions, the infrastructures are in place to continue to maintain this camp indefinitely. STEMulate was provided to campers tuition-free with room, board, and meals provided.  

During its time at Wiley, STEMulate Summer Science and Math Camp has been growing. The 2019 STEM project served 28% more 11th and 12th graders than in the previous year, and three Wiley students had the experience of being paid mentors to the campers. Students improved on math scores. They went on field trips to two local museums, solved engineering problems through building small machines, and had an art-and-science program run by local scientist Ilea Osborne. They were able to utilize lab equipment and engage with peer-reviewed scientific literature.  

 

Internships  

Wiley College has initiated new internship partnerships during the years 2015-2019. Though again, these partnerships were put on hold for COVID-related reasons, our partners are interested in continuing these relationships into the future. Our partners at Caddo Lake Biocontrol hope to continue working with Wiley students every year.  

The internship with Caddo Biocontrol has been covered in the local newspaper, the Marshall News-Messenger, and in Texas Monthly Magazine. Wiley interns have had the opportunity to present their findings at the local radio show, KMHT, the local Rotary Club, and the city council of Uncertain, Texas, as well as presenting their research to STEMulate campers.  

 

Supplemental Assistance for Math Classes  

Wiley College was able to provide math labs for 2021 Summer Bridge math students, giving them additional tools for math success. These math labs were strongly correlated with a reduction in D/F scores in college math classes.  

 

Specifically, out of 30 total students who took math courses in Summer Bridge with a lab in 2021, zero students received a D and only one student received an F. By contrast, in 2019, when there was no math lab offered, there were seven D’s and four F’s out of a total of 30 students.  

 

Labster  

Wiley College has initiated a new partnership with virtual lab service Labster, which allows students virtual access to expensive and high-tech laboratory equipment. Labster was adopted as a flexible response to COVID-related shutdowns. However, the advantages and popularity of Labster have convinced us to continue this relationship going forward.  

 

Faculty Grantsmanship Program  

Wiley College was able to host several grantsmanship chats, hosted by Ms. Charlette Edwards. Wiley College was also able to award a small grant to professors for independent projects.  

The awardee was Spanish professor Dr. Sinia Harris. Dr. Harris created the Wiley College Spanish Outreach Project for Academic Service Learning. Students translated Spanish in real-world Spanish translation scenarios, such as translating diplomas and medical documents for Spanish-speaking residents.  

In the summer of 2021, all interested faculty and admin were afforded scholarships to take a grant writing class online through the University of Georgia, paid for by the grant. Seventeen faculty and staff took advantage of this opportunity.  

 

Improvements to Labs and Classrooms  

Thanks to the grant, Wiley College was able to order high-tech smartboards for science classrooms, as well as new graphing calculators for math classes and computers for classroom and lab use. We were also able to upgrade our biochemistry lab by ordering cutting-edge laboratory equipment.  

  

American Chemical Society Formation  

Wiley College was able to form a students’ chapter of the American Chemical Society due to the grant. That will allow students access to professional contacts going forward. The Wiley College chapter of the American Chemical Society has 10 members and acquired a $300 start-up grant.  

 

Wiley College Physics Minor  

Wiley College physics minor has completed its research phase and has been approved by the Academic Council. The grant has provided us with the funds to purchase lab equipment for the physics minor.  

 
 

Last Modified: 10/01/2021
Modified by: Stephanie Gorski
